user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of parse_http_version:
```c
static bool
parse_http_version (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                    const char *http_string,
                    size_t len)
{
  const char *const h = http_string; /**< short alias */
  mhd_assert (NULL != http_string);

  /* String must start with 'HTTP/d.d', case-sensetive match.
   * See https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9112#name-http-version */
  if ((HTTP_VER_LEN != len) ||
      ('H' != h[0]) || ('T' != h[1]) || ('T' != h[2]) || ('P' != h[3]) ||
      ('/' != h[4])
      || ('.' != h[6]) ||
      (('0' > h[5]) || ('9' < h[5])) ||
      (('0' > h[7]) || ('9' < h[7])))
  {
    connection->rq.http_ver = MHD_HTTP_VER_INVALID;
    transmit_error_response_static (connection,
                                    MHD_HTTP_BAD_REQUEST,
                                    REQUEST_MALFORMED);
    return false;
  }
  if (1 == h[5] - '0')
  {
    /* HTTP/1.x */
    if (1 == h[7] - '0')
      connection->rq.http_ver = MHD_HTTP_VER_1_1;
    else if (0 == h[7] - '0')
      connection->rq.http_ver = MHD_HTTP_VER_1_0;
    else
      connection->rq.http_ver = MHD_HTTP_VER_1_2__1_9;

    return true;
  }

  if (0 == h[5] - '0')
  {
    /* Too old major version */
    connection->rq.http_ver = MHD_HTTP_VER_TOO_OLD;
    transmit_error_response_static (connection,
                                    MHD_HTTP_HTTP_VERSION_NOT_SUPPORTED,
                                    REQ_HTTP_VER_IS_TOO_OLD);
    return false;
  }

  connection->rq.http_ver = MHD_HTTP_VER_FUTURE;
  transmit_error_response_static (connection,
                                  MHD_HTTP_HTTP_VERSION_NOT_SUPPORTED,
                                  REQ_HTTP_VER_IS_NOT_SUPPORTED);
  return false;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No code fragments in parse_http_version appear to be statically unreachable. Reasoning: the top-level guard (len and character checks) gates entry to the main logic; subsequent branches depend on the runtime value of h[5] and h[7] (digits '0'..'9') so the three major-branch outcomes (major == 1, major == 0, major >= 2) are all reachable at runtime. There are no statements after unconditional returns, no mutually contradictory constant conditions, and no compile-time constant expressions that would render a branch impossible. The mhd_assert does not introduce unreachable code (it may be a no-op in non-debug builds but does not hide any later code). Therefore no fragments need investigation for Rule 2.1 (unreachable code).
